comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: According to NYT article: Many Social Events at Hot Springs on November 1, 1908 query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9403EFDA103EE233A... Gladys Ingalls is the daughter of Mrs. Melville E. Ingalls. Mother and daughter were "at home informally on Sunday afternoons" in Hot Springs, Va that Fall. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A0DE7D6113BE633A... in September, 1913, indicates that she played in tennis and putting competitions. She raised money for the Red Cross League that same year. query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9D03EEDF123FE633A... and gets frequent mentions in society columns of the NYT

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Her father was Melville Ezra Ingalls, a Massachusetts legislator who then became president of the Cleveland, Cincinnati, Chicago and St. Louis Railroad (the Big Four Railroad) as well as the Chesapeake and Ohio Railroad, See www.nationmaster.com/encyclopedia/Melville-E.-Ingalls and www.indianahistory.org/library/manuscripts/collection_gui...

comment.author: 11478098@N07
comment._content: Gladys Ingalls married Malcolm Arnold Robertson, a British diplomat, in 1917.   They met when he was first secretary in the British Embassy in Washington, and left for Europe in 1918.   Subsequently he was knighted, became Ambassador to Argentina, then an MP and chairman of a public company, and head of the British Council during the second world war.   He died in 1951.   Gladys remained in London, wanting to live near her one surviving son and his family, until her death in 1977.
